In addition, we did not identify any significant changes to our business processes, systems, and controls to support recognition and disclosure requirements under the new guidance. We adopted the provisions of Topic 606 in fiscal 2019 utilizing the modified retrospective method. The adjustments primarily related to the timing of recognition of certain customer charges, trade promotional expenditures, and volume discounts.

results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response: The answer to the question is provided in the table below.
results.csv_string_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market is determined with reference to the inputs listed above. The fair value of these instruments is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or liability, taking into account any of the following, where applicable:
• The fair value of the financial instrument;
• The risk-free rate (the risk-free rate is the rate that is assumed to be applicable to the financial instrument); and
• The yield to maturity of the financial instrument.
The market price of an asset or liability is the price at which the asset or liability would change hands between market participants in an active market if the market were completely transparent and efficient. The market price of an asset or liability is generally determined by quoting prices from exchanges or market dealers.
results.json_rows_response:
The fair value of the Group’s financial instruments (that is, those that are not traded in active markets) is determined with reference to the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value (that is, the inputs are categorised into three levels within a fair value hierarchy).
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined with reference to quoted market prices at the end of the reporting period.
A market is regarded as active if quoted prices are readily and regularly available from an exchange, dealer, broker, industry group, pricing service, or regulatory agency, and those prices represent actual and regularly occurring market transactions on an arm’s length basis.
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market is determined by using valuation techniques.
Specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments mainly include:
• Dealer quotes for similar instruments;
• The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves; and
• Other techniques, such as discounted cash flow analysis, are used to determine fair value for financial instruments.
